MN 0gdinst c0Gch. A novel race took place
yesterday sc'night: Mctcalt, the pedestrian, on
enquiring at the White Horse Cellar, was dis.
appointed in not being able to obtain an outside
place on any OF the Hampton coaches. Not
wishing to go inside, he preferred the use Of his
legs, and for a small wager, agreed to run to
Hampton distance Of IA miles, sooner than the
coach. They started together, and kept so to
Kew Green, where the coach changed horses. .--
Metcaf kept jogging OH, made little play and
actually beat the coach into Hampton by twenty
five minutes. The latter did the distance in less
than two hours.


MspherG, the Yorkshire runner will run thirty
miles against time, on Tuesday at Mill Wall, to
start at half past two. He is matched to do the
distance in three hours and a half, and to run a
mile in and mile out.

coaches make gentlemen come to London on
every small occasion, which otherwise they
would not do but upon urgent necessity; nay,
the convenience of the passage makes their
wives often come up, who rather than come
such journeys on horse back, would stay at home
Here, when they have conc to town, they must

Feuer and .fgue.-Take two ounces OF
Peruvian bark, of powdered cloves. and
of cream of tartar; mix them together; d.
vide the composition into IL equal doses.
and take one dose every morning, noon, ana
night, till the complaint is checked; then one
every morning till the whole is taken. Each
dose may be taken in glass OF any kind OF
spirituous liquor mixed i'll water.-Emfori-

! Pciocity If Sund A paper by DIR. Gregory
was read at a late meeting of the Cambridge fhl-
losophical Society, containing an account OF some
experiments made, in order to determine the Ve-
loctv with which sound is transmitted through
the atmosphere. Some of the results OF these
experiments are the following;


That wind greatly affects sound in point OF IN
tensify, and that it affects it in point OF voocl-





with that of the sound, the sum of their separate
velocities gives the apparent velocity ot sound;
when the direction of the wind opposes that OF
the sound, the HDcrence of the separate veloci.
ties must be taken; that in the case OF echoes.
the velocity of the refecied sound is the same
as that of the direct sound, and that, therefore,
distances may frequently be measured by means
of echoes; finally, that an augmentation ot tenn
perature occasions an augmentation OF the volo-
city OF sound, and rice perSa.

Ne4poltan, that if he cannot hire boy 70

Al night there was great display of fire
work, on the river and several large junks
were most brilliantly illuminated with a
large number ot lamps, arranged with such
taste and fancy, a, to produce very fine ef-
lect as they passed down the stream. This
we were told was Il peace Offering to the
De7R.


he following evening was much ANUS
ed. with party ot gamblers, under the
windows OF our factory, who pursued their
game VITA philosophical gravity, expressing
ty their couhtenances, neither exultation at
winning nor regret at losing their money!
50 much are the Chinese addicted to this
vice, that am Informed man seldom goes
abroad without a pack or a pair Of cards in
his pocket. Both of these instruments of
gaming are very different from those of Eu-
rope; their cards being much more nnmcr-
Gus and the games more complicated. They
sometimes play at chess also. This spirit
OF gaming is so universal, that almost in ey-
ry bye corner, groups are to be found play
ing cards or throwing dice.


In the evening party of us went through
the Uongs OF Qunqua, Youqua and Ponki-
qua, security merchants, which were splen-
didly decorated and illuminated with varle-
gated lamps, artificial flowers, and varie-
ty of other ornaments in honor of the Devil,
or QHi, as he is called by the Chinese. Eu
rop"ans and Americans go by the name OF
fangiti. or Strange Devil. to which they
not unfre9uently add the term of QuiSi, that
means rogue, rascal, knave, or any thing
bad.


The Sun shines no Sabbath day" in
China. tn the Chinese all days are alike.
and Europeans as we'll as our own country
men, seem to slide into the same custom with
great deal of facility, They transact busi~
ness on that day just the same as through
the week.


The first and the few succeeding days OF
the new year are the only holidays, as tar
as can learn, observed by the Chinese -
Az this time the poorest peasant makes
point of having new suit of clothes for HIM
self and his family, while they pay visits to
their friend and relations, interchanglng cl-
Whites and compliments and make and re-
ceive presents.


The fever and ague and dysentery gener-
ally prevail here about the latter part of Oc-
tober These diseases together with the
cholera morbus and bilious chollc, constitute
the principal complaints Of the seamen at
Whampoa. They may be readily account
ed for bv the immense tracts OF marsh, COW
cred with rice and paddy, which bound the
river. extending back several miles, ana
overhown almost every high tide.

DEAR fRIrNDs,


Ne who have been permitted to assemble
TO transact the concerns of this meeting.
have rcvtrcntl, to acknowledge that it has
been good for VS. that we have come togcth-
CT. It has been a comfort to behold the
countcnances one of another; and to be SEN
siblc of IL prevalence Of that Christian love
and fellowship, which invigorates the mind,
as VIC pass along the arduous path of life
Aud VIC believe it TO he duty to inform all
onr beloved brethren and sisters, that the
Lord. in his continued mercy, has enabled
MS to proceed in the deliberations of this
meeting, in much bro,herly love.


What then, dear friends, prevents our
becoming wholly spiritual-mjndcd people,
"a church, though small, wtll compacted
and fitted together, and built UP IN Christ Ic-
SuS, our Lord? We fear that sin and trans
grcssien are separating some amongst US
from Him, and thus preventing them from
becoming living branches in the true Vine.
o. that such would apply in faith to the
great PLY scian; unto Him who hath loved
us freely, who would heal cur diseases, and
present MS faultless before the presence of
Hi. glory. May We al narrowly examine
ourselves in the light of Chiiit, aud see how
ftr we arc engaged each To do his part we'll;
that we NAV, as a religions body, sh!ne with
brightness: with that brightness, which, if
the fault were not our own, thc Lord, in his
unmeried goodnt IS, would Cause 10 break
forth amongst us.


Vital Christianity consistcth not in words
but in power; and however important it is
that we have right apprehension of the
doctrines OF the Gospel, this avallcth not, un-
less we are regeneratcd by the power of the
Holy Ghost We therefore tenderly en-
treat all to wait in humble faith for its quick
ening Influence; and to seek to have our
hearts contrited before the Lord. Then we
believe that they will know for themselves
ef fIis great goodness: and as they continue,
from time to time, protiting by what they
may learn of the way of salvation, but not
trusting to it, they will partake of that living
bread which cometh down from heayen;---
they will drink of those living waters which
nourish the soul unto eternal lite. This
course CT Christian experience we earnestly
desire for every one amongst us. 1t is an
| individual work; but it is indispensable for
| all. 1t may often be SLOW IN ITS progress,
but it is certain in its effects; and amongst
the blsssed consequences which it produces,


we come to have an establishment in Christ,
resulting not from any speculative system OF
belief, but from heartfelt acquaintance


with His power inwardly revealed to the


seul. When assailed by false doctrines, OF


when in the support of our views of Chris


tim practice, trials are our portion, knowing


in whom we have believed, we can look in
4 humble, but firm reliance unto Him. Resig.
nation under the varied trials incident to hu
man lite, is often the happy attainment o
the patient, Christian traveller: these ma,
arise to him from outward Affections, or from


the privations of the society of faithful
!, Christian friends: he may be cast down froT
5 not feeling those evidences of the love C
J God, or of the clear guidance of the Spirit o
, Truth, which his soul would desire. But
r frequent recurrence to past mercies, and Il
c numheress blessings still bestowed Upon US

0foOea6ie Cog, Shur, or Beuel Gearing


We have examined an Improvement in
spur or beyel gearing for mills and other
machinery, recently invented by Mr.. Charles
Neer, an ingenious and Industrious mechanic
of this village, for which he has obtained "a
patent. The improvement consists in, the
introduction of side plates OF cast iron for the
rim of the wheel, instead of seguents of
wood, and in the manner OF fitting in and Sc
curing the cogs. For the purpose of fixing
the cogs between the plates thsre are bars
across the insice of the plates Increasing in
width towards the verge, so as TO leave
grooves of equal width across the plates fol-
the cogs. The bars hayc each groove

running throughout their length except
about one fourth OF an inch at the verge. to
render the castings as light as possible
There is small bar across each OF the spa
ces made for the cogs little nearer the in
terror edge of the rim than the verge. a
small grove made across the edge OF the
cegs embraces these bars which keeps the
cogs ia their proper length. The arms are
fastened to the rim by extending them
across the side plate on one side Of the rim
and boiling them by screw bolts passing
through the rim, assisted by as many more
as may be necessary, are made TO tasten the
side plates together The cogs, are when
first made of sufficient length inside the rim
to admit of their being brought outward Sc.
veral wearings. In case cog is broken or
unfit for use, its place can be supplied with
another, with little, or no interruption to
the mill. as these cogs are of the same width
and can be put in ard fastened. This i'm
provement combines the strength of cast
iron wheels, (and by fax more durable with
the stiffness in running, which is found in
wooden ones. There is a wheel now finish
ed at the shop of Petit and Neer, which ma
chinists and mill wrights are invited to call
and examine. Two Of these wheels will


in few days be put in operation in mill
at Glens's Falls. We hesitate not to pro-
nonncc the above very important improve
ment, and deserving the patronage OF the
public Itatevord Recorder.

Courage, mother'' cried Everell, re-

and in brief space Mr.. Pynchon with six

In the mean time the tragedy was proceed
ing at Bethel Mrs Fletcher's senses had been
stunned with terror. She had neither spoken
nor moved after she grasped her infant. t.v
erell's gallant nterpostion, restored mo-
mentsry consciousness; she screamed to hlm
--"Fly, Everell, my son, fly; for your ia

''Never''' he replied, springing to his mo

The savases, always rapid in their move
~ eats, were now aware that their safety
depended on despatch. "Finsh your work,
WARRIORS" cried Mononotto. Obedient to
the command. ard infuriated by his bleeding

had staggered back and leaned against the
wall now sprang forward, and tore the in
fant from its mothers breast. She shrek
ed, and in that shrek passed the agony OF
death. She was unconscious that her son,
putting forth strength beyond nature, tor
moment kept the Indian at bay; she neither
saw nor felt the knife struck at her own
heat. She felt not the arms of her defend
ers, Everell and Msgawisca, as thev met
around her neck. She tainted, and fell TO
ihe floor, dragging her impotent protectors
with her.


The savage, in his struggle with Everell
had tossed the infant boy to the ground; he
III quite unharmed on the turf at Mouonot
to's feet. There raising his head, and look
inC IN into the chieftain's face, he probably

eous supplication, that no words could have
expressed.


Alononntto's heart melted within him; he
stopped to raise the sweet suppliant, when
one of the Mohawks hercely seized him.
tossed him wildly around his head, and
flashed him on the door stone But the silent
prayer, perhaps the celestial inspiration ot
the innocent creature was not lost. We have
had blood enough, cried Mononotto, you
have wsll avenged ne, brothers"

"a few wears since. the present Sir john
Burke, OF Glmsk, bart. travelled with his
new married lady and establishment 10
Rome, not solely for his pleasure, but as an
Irish Catholic, to pay his respects to tn"

praper steps through Cardinal G0nsalvi, to

AIRY sbsolutoh; and, il possible. an Indulgence
also; adding that Sir John might h;Hf to The
cardinal that he intended to bequcath good
deal Of his property amongst the clergy
Sir John undertook the matter, proceeded to
Rome, saw the cardinal, and, a far as the
absoIution went, succeeded. He was him
self at the same time created Marches de
Bourke Of the Holy Roman Empire and a
bull was duly made out for Sir Francis
Gonld, at a very considerable expense. Sir
John received also couple of blessed can
dies six feet long, to burn whilst the bull
was being read. Its express terms aud
conditions, however, were, provided the
penitent, Sir Francis Gould, should not a.
gain voluntarily commit the sane sins now
forgiven, (Which list mclu6ed nearly all the
sins the cardinal could think cf!;) in the
other case, the forgiveness w00l be void.
and the two sets OF sins CONT Slap apon the
soul Of Sir Francis at once, no doubt with
compound interest; and which nothing but
severe penancc, some hundred full masses,
and great deal Of mass money, woald ever
be able 20 bring him through. Sir Joan hav-
ing brought home the bull, magnifcently
enclosed, and sewed up in silk bag sealed
officially by the cardinal, Informed Sir Fran.
els Gas we were all dining together at
Horpke's FIoteD that he had that day un-
packed his luggage, mad the pope's bull per-
fectly safe, and would hand it to him in
stantly. Sir Francis asked him it's exact
pun port. Il have had two others said he,
but they are null, for | sinncd again. and 50
can't depend upon them Sir John inform
ed him OF the purport, so far as his Latin
went, when Sir Francis calmly said. MY
dear Bonrke, don't give me the bull ye. a.
while; its operation, ! hnd is only retros-
pective, and does not affect sins committed
after its delivery; why did you not bring me
one that would answer always" Such a one
would cost damned deal more" replied
Sir John. well, then said Sir Francis


send it to me in about ten DAYS or fort.
night--no sooner: it will answer then prett,

HEALTH.--Thosc who husband their
health to the prejudice cftheir duty, deserve
it not,


lnvectives against marriage are refiec.
zion upon the laws and order of society, and
1pon mans own ancestors.


WEALTH.


The consideration Of the small addition
often made by wealth to the happiness of
she possessor. may check this desire, and
vent that Instability which sometimes at
tends it.


EMPLOYMENT.


Men may find matter sufficient to busy
sheir heads and employ their hands with va
rcty, delight and satisfaction, if they will
not boldly quarrel with their own constitu-
tons, ana throw away the blessings then
hands al e filled with, because they are no
big enough to grasp every thing.


He that has taken view of the presen
age, has seen as much as if he began witf
she world, and gone to the end or 1t, for
things in all ages are of kind and of a col
cur.


WIT.


Wit, without knowledge, is a sort o
cream, which gathers in night to the top
and by skilful hand may be SOON whipped
into jro'h, but once scummed away, wha
appears underneath is only fit to be thrown
20 the hogs.


In the year 1872, when throughout Great Brit
ain only six stage.coaches were constantly going
pamphlet was written for their suppression
and among the many grave reasons given agains
Their continuance, it is stated, 'fthese stage

we may become Of the pure in heart who


shall see God. Wait then, dear friends, up


on Him: he Of good courage, and he will


strengthen your hearts.


Those who have felt the effects Of Sa-


viour's love should be otten considering whe-


ther they are making an open confession Of


Him before men, and chershins the desire


that others may become full partakers ot


the blessings Of tie Gospel We speak not


here Of the preaching Of the word highly


as we esteem this, when exercised 10 the


power and ie oil the Holy Spirit, but that


of faithful adherence to sound principle and


consistent practice. of which, in our inter-


course with the world, we ought to give
proof At the same time il is very impor-
tant that we abide in true humility and in
the fear of the Lold. and that we revercnt-
1 ly and patiently wait to know the service as
! signed tous in the Church. All, ifthey are
faithful to the manifestations of the light of
! Truth, may be employed i'll its service ::
and as they order their convel sation Alright,
though it may be i'll the private walks of
I life, others seeing their good works, may be
led to glorify our Father who is in heaven.
! We have in this meeting been led to the
reflection, that one of the great benefits q!
religious society is that il places us under
the care one Of another, and thatwc are call
ell upon to watch over each other for rood
When we see any OF our brethren or sisters
0vertaken with fault, or ncglccting an i'm
portant duty, we ought to cherish q s,lc.
tude fer their improvement; and in that
love which would le;.d them to Christ. to of.
fer such counsel or encouragement as We
may think best calculated tJ help them
Much depends or the manner in which ad-
vice is offered. and on our embracing the
right opportunity to convey it. If it should
not Immediately have II sautary effect, we
are not TO be too much discouraged: we
ought to take heed Flat we become not i'm
patient or diSconposed, but repeat our eli.
forts in the spirit Of love and torbearlnce. POW
/ hc result OF tins Christian concern tor our
TRENDS. ls often greater than is at the tinr
apparent.


In the exercise of this duty, it becomes
those who have the earliest opportunity of
knowing the faults OF ol hers. seriously 10 con
slider on all occasions whether they ought
not to endeavnr to reclaim them before they
disclose the matter to another At the same
time we believe it has often happened, that
the heightened concealment Of the errors OF
our friends from those who were best auall.
! fed to advise them, has been productive of
4
vented by All early yet prudent disclosure to
those Of greater experience.


And We recommend 10 such of our young
1 friends rs know and approve what is excel
lent, and may have been strengthened in
some degree TO practise it, not to shrink
4 from modestiy yet faithfully couuseling
I their associates in carly life when they may
be des siatins from the path of duty. A ten
4 m ySI 40
advantage, when those to whom it is given
know that their connselors are still alike
1 subject 10 the same temptations to which
they are exposed; and when, as may somc-
times happen, the relative as well as the 50 10
cial tic, may call for the extension of hand
of help.


| There is a humility and sweetness, COM
bined with noolc rmness OF character, "a
rising from the expansive nhicncc OF Chris
tian iuve, which ought to actIate all our en-
deavollrs Tor the good OF others. Strive then
dear friends, thai 10 yodr benevolent exer-
tons TO promote tue temporal, the moral, or
the religious welfare OF your fellow men,
| your whol" conditt may be marked by an
unobrusNc Christian temper; that, when
associated with yolr friends and neighbours
! on these occasions, 1t may be manifest tnat
your great concern is to live under the infiu
cncc OF that " isAom which us from abo .c


which is pure. pclrcaklc, gentle, and easy
to be cntreatcd without partiality and with
out hypocrisy, full OF mercy, and fun ofgood
fruits. The pure exercise of Christian kind
ness brings with it its own reward; but to
be pure, it must have its origin in the love
OF God, which produces love to man; and
the satisfaction is never 81 great, the efforts
arc never 50 steady, Il, when we continually
bear IN mind, that we are to commit all our
exertionS 10 the bl s,inys of Him whose
providential eye is over all aud who is con-
tinually caring for the workmanship of His
holy hand.


Our friends Of ireland, and Of each Of the
Yearly Meetings in A;nerica have been
brought to our remembrance with fcrlngs
of Cristian love, by the reading Of the Epis
tics which they have reSpe, t'v ly addressed
to us. 1t has been very acceptabe To fad
that our brethren on the nther side Of the
Atlantic are in various places alive to the
enormities OF Slavery; and diligent to eX
pose the iniGuity of the internal Slave trade,
carried on IN the southern and Southwest
ern States of the Union. The desolating
and widely extended effects of this dreadful
traffic, whether we turn our attention to At
RIGA, to America, and the West India Islands,
or to other parts of the globe, are indeed t.
normous and distre s,ing. Much remains to
be done before this foul disgrace is removed
| from the Christian name: but we are com

1t is fourteen years since the last snow
fell in Lisbon. DR.. II. was in his chase when
it began; the driver leapcd oH-'syou may
get home how YOU can, said he, ''as for my
part must make the best use | can Of the
little time this world will last-and away he
ran into the next church.

Lost at sea and never found.

MN 0gdinst c0Gch. A novel race took place
yesterday sc'night: Mctcalt, the pedestrian, on
enquiring at the White Horse Cellar, was dis.
appointed in not being able to obtain an outside
place on any OF the Hampton coaches. Not
wishing to go inside, he preferred the use Of his
legs, and for a small wager, agreed to run to
Hampton distance Of IA miles, sooner than the
coach. They started together, and kept so to
Kew Green, where the coach changed horses. .--
Metcaf kept jogging OH, made little play and
actually beat the coach into Hampton by twenty
five minutes. The latter did the distance in less
than two hours.


MspherG, the Yorkshire runner will run thirty
miles against time, on Tuesday at Mill Wall, to
start at half past two. He is matched to do the
distance in three hours and a half, and to run a
mile in and mile out.


A few DAYS ago, an officer of the 5.h TIussars,
for a wager Of 10 guineas, undertook to walk
At Brighton. in his favor, by txo seconds only.


Mrs. M'Nuller is now Al Carlisle, where She
has heen walking ninety-two ml"s in twenty.
four hours, for tie amusement OF I'll. IDLE portion
OF the inhabitants.


H,6pio9. .-lackson will Tomorrow hop his
match for 800 sovereigns, on Blaekheath. The
undertaking is to hon seyenty.cHc Yards il TWEEN
~ hops. Twelve O'clock is the hour appointed.


On Friday week. bnat given by Mr. Kean,
to be called the ''Sir Giles Ovcrrc4ch," Will be
rowed for at the Red House Tavern, Ba,tcrsca,
on which occasion Mr. kcan will appear il his
canoe in the costume ofan Indian Chief

coaches make gentlemen come to London on
every small occasion, which otherwise they
would not do but upon urgent necessity; nay,
the convenience of the passage makes their
wives often come up, who rather than come
such journeys on horse back, would stay at home
Here, when they have conc to town, they must
presently be in the mode, get fine clothes, go to
plays, and treats, and by these means get SUCH
habit of idleness and love Of pleasure, that they
are uneasy ever after"


Feuer and .fgue.-Take two ounces OF
Peruvian bark, of powdered cloves. and
of cream of tartar; mix them together; d.
vide the composition into IL equal doses.
and take one dose every morning, noon, ana
night, till the complaint is checked; then one
every morning till the whole is taken. Each
dose may be taken in glass OF any kind OF
spirituous liquor mixed i'll water.-Emfori-
I'M,


! Pciocity If Sund A paper by DIR. Gregory
was read at a late meeting of the Cambridge fhl-
losophical Society, containing an account OF some
experiments made, in order to determine the Ve-
loctv with which sound is transmitted through
the atmosphere. Some of the results OF these
experiments are the following;


That wind greatly affects sound in point OF IN
tensify, and that it affects it in point OF voocl-





with that of the sound, the sum of their separate
velocities gives the apparent velocity ot sound;
when the direction of the wind opposes that OF
the sound, the HDcrence of the separate veloci.
ties must be taken; that in the case OF echoes.
the velocity of the refecied sound is the same
as that of the direct sound, and that, therefore,
distances may frequently be measured by means
of echoes; finally, that an augmentation ot tenn
perature occasions an augmentation OF the volo-
city OF sound, and rice perSa.

Ne4poltan, that if he cannot hire boy 70

(QH{1n

CANTON.
full articles.article:
Al night there was great display of fire
work, on the river and several large junks
were most brilliantly illuminated with a
large number ot lamps, arranged with such
taste and fancy, a, to produce very fine ef-
lect as they passed down the stream. This
we were told was Il peace Offering to the
De7R.


he following evening was much ANUS
ed. with party ot gamblers, under the
windows OF our factory, who pursued their
game VITA philosophical gravity, expressing
ty their couhtenances, neither exultation at
winning nor regret at losing their money!
50 much are the Chinese addicted to this
vice, that am Informed man seldom goes
abroad without a pack or a pair Of cards in
his pocket. Both of these instruments of
gaming are very different from those of Eu-
rope; their cards being much more nnmcr-
Gus and the games more complicated. They
sometimes play at chess also. This spirit
OF gaming is so universal, that almost in ey-
ry bye corner, groups are to be found play
ing cards or throwing dice.


In the evening party of us went through
the Uongs OF Qunqua, Youqua and Ponki-
qua, security merchants, which were splen-
didly decorated and illuminated with varle-
gated lamps, artificial flowers, and varie-
ty of other ornaments in honor of the Devil,
or QHi, as he is called by the Chinese. Eu
rop"ans and Americans go by the name OF
fangiti. or Strange Devil. to which they
not unfre9uently add the term of QuiSi, that
means rogue, rascal, knave, or any thing
bad.


The Sun shines no Sabbath day" in
China. tn the Chinese all days are alike.
and Europeans as we'll as our own country
men, seem to slide into the same custom with
great deal of facility, They transact busi~
ness on that day just the same as through
the week.


The first and the few succeeding days OF
the new year are the only holidays, as tar
as can learn, observed by the Chinese -
Az this time the poorest peasant makes
point of having new suit of clothes for HIM
self and his family, while they pay visits to
their friend and relations, interchanglng cl-
Whites and compliments and make and re-
ceive presents.


The fever and ague and dysentery gener-
ally prevail here about the latter part of Oc-
tober These diseases together with the
cholera morbus and bilious chollc, constitute
the principal complaints Of the seamen at
Whampoa. They may be readily account
ed for bv the immense tracts OF marsh, COW
cred with rice and paddy, which bound the
river. extending back several miles, ana
overhown almost every high tide.

cur Holy Head and High Priest. the ,r.,.
christian Lawgiver.-It had no existerSrs S.as ~
the pure and earliest age of his Church. ~. a..
was gradually introduced as suners,;t;n, W,
aapostacy spread over the Christian w.a,s aaa
Il IS further our belief, and it has been .u' m.:
tormly that of the Society, that the mr;s.N uaa-
ot the Gospel is to be without money ~"
without price: that as the gift is frss .na .,
exercise OF it is to be free also: that N. .ne S
fice is to be filled by these only VIII ~, 1
themselves called of God through thr no,' ..el
OF the holy Spirit, who in their preach;sa
as wen as in their circumspect lives and
conversation, are giving proof of this call all
forged maintenance of an established min
istry Is, III our apprehension, violation os
those great privileges, which God, in b;s
,nhn'te wisdom and goodness, designed 70
ocstow upon the human race, when he sent
ms Son to redeem the world, and bv ,hs
power OF the Holy Spirit, to lead and guido
mankind into all Truth


WHIST thus setting forth the grounds os
tn's testimony, we gratefully remember IN.
kindness with which our religious scrunl.s
are often regarded by those who have to SIN
port and enforce the laws by which we ar.
affected. arc
Dear rriehds-hs we have been permitted
at this time untedly to partake of the m,rN
cies OF our Heavenly Father, and to feel Mr
confidence in Him to be renewed, in the b,.
llef that lie is watching over us as relipioua
Society for good, may we all 80 live in his
Tear, that we may availingly pray for his
blessing; SO acknowledge Him in all onr
ways, that He may direct our paths whilst
here, and finally grant US an admission into
hls heavenly kingdom through Jesus Christ
our Lord.


In the love of the Gospel we cordially bid
you farewell. 'N


Signed in and on behalf of the MEETING h,,


JOSIAH FORSTER,


Clerk 20 the Meeting this Year.

full articles.article:
Bs adjournment, from the 25G nfthe Fifth Montl.,


to the SIS, Of the same, inclusive, 1897.


TO TIE Quarterly and Nuthy Mcetmgs


cfFruHds, IN Great Britain, Ireland, and


cisc5eherc.


DEAR fRIrNDs,


Ne who have been permitted to assemble
TO transact the concerns of this meeting.
have rcvtrcntl, to acknowledge that it has
been good for VS. that we have come togcth-
CT. It has been a comfort to behold the
countcnances one of another; and to be SEN
siblc of IL prevalence Of that Christian love
and fellowship, which invigorates the mind,
as VIC pass along the arduous path of life
Aud VIC believe it TO he duty to inform all
onr beloved brethren and sisters, that the
Lord. in his continued mercy, has enabled
MS to proceed in the deliberations of this
meeting, in much bro,herly love.


What then, dear friends, prevents our
becoming wholly spiritual-mjndcd people,
"a church, though small, wtll compacted
and fitted together, and built UP IN Christ Ic-
SuS, our Lord? We fear that sin and trans
grcssien are separating some amongst US
from Him, and thus preventing them from
becoming living branches in the true Vine.
o. that such would apply in faith to the
great PLY scian; unto Him who hath loved
us freely, who would heal cur diseases, and
present MS faultless before the presence of
Hi. glory. May We al narrowly examine
ourselves in the light of Chiiit, aud see how
ftr we arc engaged each To do his part we'll;
that we NAV, as a religions body, sh!ne with
brightness: with that brightness, which, if
the fault were not our own, thc Lord, in his
unmeried goodnt IS, would Cause 10 break
forth amongst us.


Vital Christianity consistcth not in words
but in power; and however important it is
that we have right apprehension of the
doctrines OF the Gospel, this avallcth not, un-
less we are regeneratcd by the power of the
Holy Ghost We therefore tenderly en-
treat all to wait in humble faith for its quick
ening Influence; and to seek to have our
hearts contrited before the Lord. Then we
believe that they will know for themselves
ef fIis great goodness: and as they continue,
from time to time, protiting by what they
may learn of the way of salvation, but not
trusting to it, they will partake of that living
bread which cometh down from heayen;---
they will drink of those living waters which
nourish the soul unto eternal lite. This
course CT Christian experience we earnestly
desire for every one amongst us. 1t is an
| individual work; but it is indispensable for
| all. 1t may often be SLOW IN ITS progress,
but it is certain in its effects; and amongst
the blsssed consequences which it produces,


we come to have an establishment in Christ,
resulting not from any speculative system OF
belief, but from heartfelt acquaintance


with His power inwardly revealed to the


seul. When assailed by false doctrines, OF


when in the support of our views of Chris


tim practice, trials are our portion, knowing


in whom we have believed, we can look in
4 humble, but firm reliance unto Him. Resig.
nation under the varied trials incident to hu
man lite, is often the happy attainment o
the patient, Christian traveller: these ma,
arise to him from outward Affections, or from


the privations of the society of faithful
!, Christian friends: he may be cast down froT
5 not feeling those evidences of the love C
J God, or of the clear guidance of the Spirit o
, Truth, which his soul would desire. But
r frequent recurrence to past mercies, and Il
c numheress blessings still bestowed Upon US

0foOea6ie Cog, Shur, or Beuel Gearing


We have examined an Improvement in
spur or beyel gearing for mills and other
machinery, recently invented by Mr.. Charles
Neer, an ingenious and Industrious mechanic
of this village, for which he has obtained "a
patent. The improvement consists in, the
introduction of side plates OF cast iron for the
rim of the wheel, instead of seguents of
wood, and in the manner OF fitting in and Sc
curing the cogs. For the purpose of fixing
the cogs between the plates thsre are bars
across the insice of the plates Increasing in
width towards the verge, so as TO leave
grooves of equal width across the plates fol-
the cogs. The bars hayc each groove

running throughout their length except
about one fourth OF an inch at the verge. to
render the castings as light as possible
There is small bar across each OF the spa
ces made for the cogs little nearer the in
terror edge of the rim than the verge. a
small grove made across the edge OF the
cegs embraces these bars which keeps the
cogs ia their proper length. The arms are
fastened to the rim by extending them
across the side plate on one side Of the rim
and boiling them by screw bolts passing
through the rim, assisted by as many more
as may be necessary, are made TO tasten the
side plates together The cogs, are when
first made of sufficient length inside the rim
to admit of their being brought outward Sc.
veral wearings. In case cog is broken or
unfit for use, its place can be supplied with
another, with little, or no interruption to
the mill. as these cogs are of the same width
and can be put in ard fastened. This i'm
provement combines the strength of cast
iron wheels, (and by fax more durable with
the stiffness in running, which is found in
wooden ones. There is a wheel now finish
ed at the shop of Petit and Neer, which ma
chinists and mill wrights are invited to call
and examine. Two Of these wheels will


in few days be put in operation in mill
at Glens's Falls. We hesitate not to pro-
nonncc the above very important improve
ment, and deserving the patronage OF the
public Itatevord Recorder.

SnermaceH Candirs. The present gene
ration, SAYS the Nantucket Journal, see TINS
article before them in such quantities. ana
the manufacture passing on before theii

The family of Rotch introduced the manu-,

This family, always in the m0ney-sct'i'S
way, equally intelligent, Industrious ana H'''
Greet, filled his Golfers, while their neiShDof'
looked on with astonishment to see the heaa
matter of the whale, come from their worhs'
an elegant Sperm Candle. It wasn't to d.
endured. The Fo!gers were always an "a
telligent family. (Dr. Franslin's grana,'s'
ther was Folgcr.) The late Walter ~
ger, 4 man OF uncommon perspicacity' az
termned 10 detect the secret, coninencen
his experiments on the Spermaceti whste
eve could not sec him, nor did he aclAd""
his object until he had completed sdccSss-
full operation. He called on Thomas jI""
kins, merchant, ard proposed to cnnnellsS
the manufacture. Jenkins doubted whe'',
err Folger had sufficient know ~ledge OF the an
when he very l-isurely drew candle tt'"t
his pocket and silenced all doubt. aehoe
forth the mystery was disclosed. and sew. ,'.
al small factories erected. Look now AZ "
vast quantities of this article Annually SNIP
ped from this place.

full articles.headline: ,ot. and the ha,chet fell harmless to the
full articles.article:
SHOT. and the Ratchet fell harmless to the
Aoor.


Courage, mother'' cried Everell, re-
loading the piece, but neither courage nor
celebrity could avail--the second Indian
aprang upon him, threw him on the foor,
wrested his musket from him, brandishihg
his tomahawk ever his head, he would nave
aimed the fatal stroke, when cry IRON
Mononotto arrested his arm


Everell extricated himself from his grasp
and La lay OF hope flashing into his mind'he se'z-
I'd bugle horn which hung beside the door,
and winded it. This was the conventional
signal of alarm-and he sent forth blast-
long and loud--a death" crv


Mrs. Grafton and her attendants were lust
mounting their horses to return home Dig
by listened tor moment-then exclalm'ng,
''it comes from our masters dwelling! ride
for your life, Hutton!' he tossed away
haneisox that cncumbered him, and spurred
his horse to his utmost speed.


The alarm was spread through the vii re,
and in brief space Mr.. Pynchon with six
armed men were pressing towards the fatal
srene.


In the mean time the tragedy was proceed
ing at Bethel Mrs Fletcher's senses had been
stunned with terror. She had neither spoken
nor moved after she grasped her infant. t.v
erell's gallant nterpostion, restored mo-
mentsry consciousness; she screamed to hlm
--"Fly, Everell, my son, fly; for your ia
theirs sake. hy!"


''Never''' he replied, springing to his mo
ther's side.


The savases, always rapid in their move
~ eats, were now aware that their safety
depended on despatch. "Finsh your work,
WARRIORS" cried Mononotto. Obedient to
the command. ard infuriated by his bleeding
wound, the Indian, who on receiving the shot
had staggered back and leaned against the
wall now sprang forward, and tore the in
fant from its mothers breast. She shrek
ed, and in that shrek passed the agony OF
death. She was unconscious that her son,
putting forth strength beyond nature, tor
moment kept the Indian at bay; she neither
saw nor felt the knife struck at her own
heat. She felt not the arms of her defend
ers, Everell and Msgawisca, as thev met
around her neck. She tainted, and fell TO
ihe floor, dragging her impotent protectors
with her.


The savage, in his struggle with Everell
had tossed the infant boy to the ground; he
III quite unharmed on the turf at Mouonot
to's feet. There raising his head, and look
inC IN into the chieftain's face, he probably
pSibCNCN q SlSd" VI hi''Syt i"' WI" WV
quick instinct of Infancy, that with uncrrlne
sagacty directs its appeal, he clasprd the
naked leg of the savage with one arm, and
stretched the other towards him with pit
eous supplication, that no words could have
expressed.


Alononntto's heart melted within him; he
stopped to raise the sweet suppliant, when
one of the Mohawks hercely seized him.
tossed him wildly around his head, and
flashed him on the door stone But the silent
prayer, perhaps the celestial inspiration ot
the innocent creature was not lost. We have
had blood enough, cried Mononotto, you
have wsll avenged ne, brothers"


Then looking at Oneco, who had remain
ca in nne corner Of the portico, clasping
Faith Leslie in his arms, he commanded
him to follow with the child. Evereil was
torn from the lifeless bodies of his mother
and sisters, and dragged into the forest
Maeawisca uttered one cry of agony and
despair, as she looked, for'the last time, on
the bloody scene, aud then followed her ia"
.her.


Ashley passed the boundary of the clear
cd grnund, Munonotto tore from Oncco his
English dress, aud casting it from him
Thus perlsl, he said, every mark of cap
tivity Of my children. Thou shalt return
20 our forests" he continued, wrapping a
skin around him, with the badge Of thy peo
pit."

full articles.headline: From Sb. iona Rqryiurton's Sketchcy.
full articles.article:
From Sir iona RGrrinStoH'S SkftchcS.


"a few wears since. the present Sir john
Burke, OF Glmsk, bart. travelled with his
new married lady and establishment 10
Rome, not solely for his pleasure, but as an
Irish Catholic, to pay his respects to tn"
pope. kiss his holincss's toe, and purrhlse
antiquities The late Sir Francis Gould,
then at Paris, requested Sir John (beforc
me. that, as he fancied he felt himself in a
declining state OF health, and unable to travel
SO far as Rome, he (Sir John) would take the
praper steps through Cardinal G0nsalvi, to
procure him, from his holiness, a bull of plea
AIRY sbsolutoh; and, il possible. an Indulgence
also; adding that Sir John might h;Hf to The
cardinal that he intended to bequcath good
deal Of his property amongst the clergy
Sir John undertook the matter, proceeded to
Rome, saw the cardinal, and, a far as the
absoIution went, succeeded. He was him
self at the same time created Marches de
Bourke Of the Holy Roman Empire and a
bull was duly made out for Sir Francis
Gonld, at a very considerable expense. Sir
John received also couple of blessed can
dies six feet long, to burn whilst the bull
was being read. Its express terms aud
conditions, however, were, provided the
penitent, Sir Francis Gould, should not a.
gain voluntarily commit the sane sins now
forgiven, (Which list mclu6ed nearly all the
sins the cardinal could think cf!;) in the
other case, the forgiveness w00l be void.
and the two sets OF sins CONT Slap apon the
soul Of Sir Francis at once, no doubt with
compound interest; and which nothing but
severe penancc, some hundred full masses,
and great deal Of mass money, woald ever
be able 20 bring him through. Sir Joan hav-
ing brought home the bull, magnifcently
enclosed, and sewed up in silk bag sealed
officially by the cardinal, Informed Sir Fran.
els Gas we were all dining together at
Horpke's FIoteD that he had that day un-
packed his luggage, mad the pope's bull per-
fectly safe, and would hand it to him in
stantly. Sir Francis asked him it's exact
pun port. Il have had two others said he,
but they are null, for | sinncd again. and 50
can't depend upon them Sir John inform
ed him OF the purport, so far as his Latin
went, when Sir Francis calmly said. MY
dear Bonrke, don't give me the bull ye. a.
while; its operation, ! hnd is only retros-
pective, and does not affect sins committed
after its delivery; why did you not bring me
one that would answer always" Such a one
would cost damned deal more" replied
Sir John. well, then said Sir Francis


send it to me in about ten DAYS or fort.
night--no sooner: it will answer then prett,


well. as an about taking away beautifu


young creature, my landlady's daughter


next week, and should have that sin to all


swer for if you gave me the bun before
